newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Democratic Republic of Congo reverts to old flag.
newsitem.headline: Democratic Republic of Congo reverts to old flag.

text.p: The newly declared Democratic Republic of Congo has restored the star-spangled national flag first adopted at independence in 1960, an official said on Monday.

Moise Myarugabo, secretary-general in the office of self-proclaimed President Laurent Kabila, told Reuters his alliance was intent on reverting to the old flag, in parallel with the decision to drop the name Zaire.

The blue and yellow flag with one large star in the centre and six smaller stars in a vertical line close to the staff flies on government buildings in parts of the country captured by the alliance in earlier stages of its seven-month rebellion.

The single star represents the united country and the smaller six represent its six original provinces. The country now has nine provinces and new authorities have not yet taken a decision to redraw boundaries.

Following the seven-month civil war Kabila on Saturday changed the name of the country to the Democratic Republic of Congo and declared himself its leader. He acted as his rebels entered Kinshasa, a day after Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko relinquished power and abandoned his capital.
Mobutu renamed Africa's third largest country as Zaire in 1971. His flag showed an arm carrying a burning torch, in a circle surrounded by a green background.

The new flag is also the flag of the now-ruling Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (AFDL). The alliance adopted it as a gesture of defiance towards all the changes made by Mobutu during his 32 years as president.
